segments.text: that they were of any real interest to the Japanese nation or the Japanese people.

But they have tried to join these investigations, and I think at the present time now in CSK, which is Cooperative Studies of the Kurashio, was an example whereby they would like to focus their efforts in the area of Japan.
But in terms of the INPFC, the Japanese, of course,
work was done by the Japanese Fishery Agency.
And they had access to Japanese oceanographic groups.
And actually, the fishery agency vessels did some studies.
But as this work progressed, and as we were searching for common terminology of fronts and features and current nomenclature currents, we received a great deal of cooperation from the Japanese.
And in the late 1950s, we would actually meet in ADAC, which is in the middle of the Aleutian Islands, and exchange data.
At that time, we had a computer aboard our ship, and we were able to give them computer printouts.
And they, of course, are very adept at these pen and ink
forms that they can fill out.
And some strategies for fishing and for investigating environmental features in the Aleutian area came about at these meetings in mid-salmon season at ADAC.
And we have published two joint reports, Bulletin 13 and Bulletin 33, which summarizes just only the top of, well, it's a severe synthesis of 20 years' work, really, is what it is.
So we've enjoyed working with them very much in the Aleutian area.
And the Oak Bay Laboratory has had excellent cooperation with them in the eastern Bering Sea to the point where the Japanese would provide the Oshiro Maru, which is their big research vessel.
This is the vessel at the Kaido University.
It's the College of Fisheries where they would, we would send people on board their ship and conduct joint studies together.
So I would say that it took a while to get started, the early 50s.
But by the end of the late 50s, and particularly the early 60s, it was just absolutely a joy to work with these groups.
And part of the rationale for continuing on the salmon studies was the fact that it was just a tremendous international exchange of information.
from an environmental standpoint and a fishery standpoint.
So even though they couldn't decide on the protocol to the treaty, which was an equitable division of salmon, they felt that this should go on.
And it's only been the last few years that the field programs have died down.
The next series of questions, I pretty well answered the questions I had about your work that I had jotted down.
The next series of questions concern really government service, for lack of a better word.
There is a move now to centralize all funding agencies of oceanography under one central agency, probably the Commerce Department, probably NOAA.
What are your feelings on that?
Well, I don't think bigger is better, and that's what would happen if you do this.
But I really feel that a lot more progress could be made a lot sooner if we had
sort of a division by area.

Say, for example, the Arctic studies, which say the Arctic and the Antarctic, the Pacific studies, the Atlantic studies, and kind of leave the Indian Ocean to fend for itself at this time because we've spent a lot of money there.
And then there are other people now that are capable of studying it.
I really would like to see a center that is responsive to the Pacific Ocean as an entity.
I don't think that this one group would satisfy that.
I would rather see it broken down into four or five groups by area rather than one single discipline center.
In some respects, I think that the National Oceanographic Data Center is an example of

The concept of having data available and the concept of insisting that people that are spending government money acquiring data turn it in in a certain established format to a central repository is fine.
But it just becomes monolithic to handle this.
And I think it could be better done on this.
One suggestion I would have instead of a National Oceanographic Data Center, they had one on the east coast for the Atlantic and one on the west coast for the Pacific.
And I think it would accelerate the studies.
It would avoid a lot of duplication and provide a focus for what should be done in these areas.
Nature of grant giving.
At one time, certainly very early in your career, most grant giving
was sort of done by ONR and intended to be sort of divided between research of R&D based upon peer research and mission oriented research.
Since then, there was a lot of criticism of that for various reasons.
And since then too now, the grant giving having gone out of NSF and what have you, various government contracts types.
The arguments go two ways.
One, that in ONR there was too much in-house review.
That is, the government was guilty of that.
And secondly, that now that they're afraid the same thing is happening in government contracts, and that the NSF way of reviewing each grant separately and so forth is better.
Now, that sort of jumbled sentence, if you can make any sense out of it, I'd like some comments on that.
What do you think about in-house reviews?
How do you see your role as a reviewer out of house since you make comments on NSF grants?
What do you think about the present funding structure, and how would you change it?
Well, I'm really not sure what you're driving at, but I know sort of peripherally this business of peer review versus in-house and out-house reviews.
My own feeling is, and I think that's of a lot of people, that this becomes kind of clannish or kind of cliquish.
And there are many indications of this.

I think there are still strong feelings in the community that probably people aren't going to voice that, say, Woods Hole and Scripps have too much of a say in what is done in terms of academic funding.
It's kind of hard to break into this.
They can become quite hostile.
And I don't know whether this is subjective or not, in the sense that because the ocean is so large and because it is so complex, it's almost easy to be negative on any proposal.
You know that this person, even if he has some experience
is probably not going to be able to answer his question satisfactorily because of this thing.
The whole ocean is a turbulent regime, and it just requires tremendous resources to study it and to monitor it.
And I think that any reviewer can, you know, on any given day say yes to something he said no to the other day.
So this becomes sort of a clannish group that your friend's projects are approved.
And I don't think you asked that specifically, but I think that's the heart of it.
And although NSF tries to change their desks quite frequently, really they're still bringing in people from the same places to sit at the desks.
And all I can say is, on the whole, I think the money is distributed fairly well.
But I think there are a few people that have too much of the lion's share of it.
Well, that's not exactly what I was answering, but that's a good enough answer.
That certainly explains what I think we need to know about it.
Also now, a controversy is raging, beginning with the idea of the 200-mile limit, on where should oceanography work.
Should it move back towards the continental shelves, where most of the species exist?
and how the 200-mile limits will affect both fishing and oceanographic research.
So how about some comments on that?
I don't think that oceanography should retreat to 200 miles because if there's anything that we learned, it's that there is continuity throughout the whole world oceans.
And if you limit yourself to just sort of a coastal study, your time frame is so short.
You're able to measure and observe what's there, but you have no way of ascertaining how it's going to change in the next week or even the next month until you know something upstream and we know.
Of course, on this coast, everything out is.
We have a unique onshore flow here.
So I think that's one of the fallacies of saying, well,
convenient to work on the coast, we have good visibility.
If we put our ships on the coast and the ground fisheries are concentrated on the coast, let's study it.
I can't subscribe to the fact that we just give up the open ocean studies and come into the coast.
I think we should have a total ocean study.
And given a total ocean study, at that point, we can concentrate within the 200 miles.
Now, I think what will happen is that we're going to find just I think even oceanographers are going to be surprised at the complexity of flow within the 200-mile regime.
We all have a tendency to simplify, and sometimes the data only permits you a simple picture of what's going on.
And I envision once the 200-mile limit is
that these fisheries councils are devoting their efforts to.

Once the 200-mile regime is clarified as to the kinds and numbers of fish that are there that are going to be commercial fish that are going to be caught either by foreign nations or our nations, that there will be another U.N. cry such as the one in the 50s
to do the environmental measurements that will provide insight into why they are moving as they do and into a predictive regime.
And so I guess that's my best answer, that I think we still have to deal with the oceans as a total concept and that we should concentrate.
but not to the exclusion of offshore, and when we do, we'll find the time and space scales that are necessary to really pin down what's going on in the coastal areas, surprising to everyone.
Do you think the 200-mile limit will hurt American fishermen?
Well, of course, that's a loaded question in a fishery center because it does hurt some and not hurt others, but I, as an individual, am very...
I'm very pleased that we have established this notion of the responsibility and the protection of this.
It's a little grander than the scheme I proposed 10 years ago.
I proposed to Dr. McHugh, who is now at Sunnybrook, and he was director of research, that the fishery should be responsible for the continental shelf and what happens
to it, in other words, out to the shelf.
At this time, you know, we had three miles that was not necessarily ascribed to fisheries.
My concept was that the National Fisheries Service should be responsible for the environment, for the protection of it, and to obtain information on it.
And actually, at the time, he felt this was a good idea, but it was something that passed in the night.
And so now we have 200 miles.
I think we have a very interesting, perhaps 10 or 20 years ahead, to pin down these swirls and eddies that pass through this 200-mile zone that are going to affect the fisheries.
As you look at a coastal fishery, most of these are ground fisheries, and their guideposts, their pathways are oriented to the bottom.
But I still think that...
These pulses that come from the ocean regimes have a great deal to do as to how they move on the bottom.
And we'll find that out in the future.
In terms of technology, what sorts of things do you think that oceanography most needs to advance the discipline?
What sort of inventions would you like to have most?
Well, I really haven't given any specific thought to that because I don't think we've exploited the equipment that we have.
What we need is precise measurement of a large area of the ocean surface.
I should have said area, but of course it's three-dimensional.
We need to know the conditions from the surface to bottom and how they change.
And we have the equipment for that, with moored buoys, with buoys with releases, with buoys that can be tracked by satellite.
Really, the question is, do we want to spend the money for it?
And if you remember these buoy plans that came up, I think they were 500 or 1,000 buoys off our coast, and people felt they would be hazards to navigation and what have you.
I was for that.
I think that's where we have to go.
I don't know of any other instrument you could ask for, including satellites, that would give you the information that would come from these buoys of rays.
I think they'll come eventually, but what form they'll take, I haven't given any other thought to.
in terms of advice to young oceanographers, may we say.
What sort of advice would you give one?
What discipline should he enter?
Like, for example, nuclear engineering was probably the hot, I suppose, oceanographic device in the 1960s.
What's going to be at the 1970s?
Well, if you're looking for a key word, I think obviously the key word, and these key words come every three to five years, I think the present key word is climate.
And I don't think there is another one beyond climate.
And as you think of climate, the ocean is inextricably linked with climate.
And we haven't even begun to study this aspect.
There are several programs.
But air-sea interaction is a word that people have kicked around for 20 or 30 years, and yet we still don't have a good handle on this.
And so I would say that ocean studies will continue under the guise of climate, which has an effect on agriculture.
It has built into it an association with meteorology and what have you.
And I think it's sort of a good umbrella to deal with and an important area of study.
As far as what information would you give to somebody studying oceanography, it's really
It's up to the individual, I think.
I don't think you can give anybody any real instruction.
You have really an interest in something or you don't.
And if you have the interest in it, you associate it with it as sort of an all-consuming drive to study it and work with it.
And I think if you have it, then intuitively you will find the area of the ocean.
And certainly there are many facets to it
where you can devote this energy to it.
I'm a little concerned about people that recruit people to study the ocean.
I don't think that that's necessary.
The thing that I would tell someone that wanted to get into it is that it is perhaps sort of trite in the sense that it's a new frontier.
And it's not really a new frontier.
The oceans have been around a long time.
But we know so little about them that any contribution is going to be recorded and people will lean on and build on.
And I don't think we're going to understand the oceans to the degree
that we want to, much less the degree we need to for many, many decades.
And so it's an exciting period for someone who wants to devote their life to a study.
It isn't something that's going to dry up and be old hat in 10 or 20 years.
The necessity of integrating this, the necessity of understanding all the forces,
We're really pioneers.

I really think if someone could look ahead 100 years from now, that even the people that are coming into the field now will really still be considered pioneers, and that they will still be studying the oceans for a long time to come.
And that should be, if someone really is interested in it, that should be enough incentive to really let them build a career on it.
Have you ever had any regrets about choosing government service rather than the academic world?
Not a bit.
Not really.
They both have their drawbacks, and it's kind of hard to put me on the spot where so many people are going to read this.
But I think that...
Government can become very restrictive.
I think that I've been fortunate to live in a period where we've sort of been developing our own guidelines.
In other words, the fishery is so vague, the ocean is so vague, that we've had a great deal of latitude within budget limitations to study just this myriad of questions that we have.
I really can't say whether the next 10 or 20 years that this freedom will still exist.
In fact, I'm asking for some reduction in it when I ask for it.
integrated studies, or at least people working together.
You lose freedom when you do that.
But no, I've seriously considered teaching.
In fact, Dr. Fleming felt I would be very good at it, and I did too.
But I've been very, very pleased with my choice.
Now, the next series of questions, if you should like, are what we call predictive questions, which always puts a scientist and a historian on the spot, since neither of us ever like to do that.
Miraculture and aquaculture.
Will it be successful?
Will it not be successful?
Are you optimistic?
Are you not optimistic?
In what direction will it go in?
Well, it doesn't really behoove me to answer that because this is kind of a troubled area in the National Marine Fisheries Service now.
I think that all I can say about it is that it is a high-risk venture and always will be.
I think there are opportunities for considerable profit.
In a high-risk industry, there are opportunities for somebody really to lose money.
I personally love shellfish because of the diet of fish in World War II that was subjected to or given to midshipmen.
I really find that my fish diet is limited, but my shellfish one is a preferable diet for me.
In fact, lobster to me is ambrosia.
There's nothing more.
The biggest steak in the world.
I could pass up very easily the most tasty one for a lobster.
That's what I consider really elegant.
And yet I must admit that aquaculture using purified or sewerage or perhaps heated waters from a radioactive effluent or something
I'm not so sure my palate would respond the same to that, an organism raised in captivity versus the one that I'm used to.
And I think it's subjective, but it still would pose a problem for me.
Well, you actually hinted at it.
What about pollution in the oceans?
What do you feel like is the major danger?
How great is the danger in terms of pollution?
Clearly, the sea is not dying, despite what Jacques Cousteau says.
And what kind of control should there be?
I would answer it.
I'm pretty much joined with your initial sentiments that I think that Cousteau is an alarmist.
But I think there's a role for someone that wants to do that today.
because of these alarms that this word is getting to people who really have never considered the ocean before.
They live inland.
They don't see it.
They don't travel on it.
To them, it's something that is just there in geography.
And so he's getting a lot of support, and I applaud him for it.
And I see a long-term difficulty without some restraints.
But I really feel that man...
will impose restraints where and when they are needed.
And I have no fear, as you say, of a polluted ocean.
Tankers are a short-term phenomenon.
Who knows?
Most of the oil reserves we have are 20 or 30 years.
And this is just a passing phase in terms of oceans.
I am concerned about the long term.
the sinking of radioactive waste.
I think that's a terrible mistake.
But I don't know.
I have to put it in the proper focus.
And everybody says the oil is polluted.

If you get in a raft and you find garbage in the ocean, well, you have to consider in World War II, with the limited shipping we had, there was great restraint on dumping garbage over the sides so that the U-boat might find the convoy had been through.
If we really went to that extreme in those days, there must have been garbage in the ocean too.

It's kind of inconceivable that we went to such great efforts not to dump anything of anything over the side in the middle of a huge ocean thousands of miles across that a U-boat would find it or would track trails.

So I think, with the cautions and the restraints that have been put on the tankers, that perhaps we are not polluting the oceans any more than was done by the large shipping with utter abandon, say, in the 30s and 40s, when literally they cleaned ship outside the harbor.
They literally piled stuff up on decks.
The minute they could drop the pilot, they would dump it.
So as an oceanographer, I'm concerned as to what could happen, but I'm not on the alarmist team at this point.

Are there any, well, beside radioactive waste, are there any particular types of things that you're worried about, particularly in terms of the relationship to salmon, which you know a great deal about, any type of pollutants which affect animal life in the city?
Well, all I can say is, of course, man has the potential to spoil the ocean.
But I just think that regulations will come along by people that are aware of the contamination that comes along.
By that, I'm saying we don't need a multimillion or billion dollar
monitoring program to guard against ocean pollution.
If we're going to pollute it, we know the people are either carrying it to sea or they're dumping it in the rivers.
And I think that the cleanup that has been started will suffice.
I hope I'm not proven wrong.
But that would be my feel.
Good enough.
Now, these next series of questions are sort of historic interest questions.
What probably single discovery in oceanography, let's say in the last 20 years, surprised you the most?
What do you think was the most important discovery as far as oceanographers were concerned?
Well, in terms of there are various phases.
I think the plate theories are some of the more interesting ones that have come along.
This finding of heated thermal plumes at death of the Galapagos Islands and in the Red Sea, we've always considered that these could exist.
I think these are interesting, but I don't think that these are purely observational things.
I find that the most exciting thing that's happened in the last 20 years is really the ability to simulate some of the complex phenomena in the huge computer.
But although I am interested and intrigued by this, I'm also somewhat disappointed in the sense that it looks like something that people are going to play with for another 20 years.
My feeling is that here again, coordination is greatly needed.
I think everybody at a university today is compelled to deal with a computer problem, to deal with some kind of a model.
And it's inconceivable that we need all of these people building all of these little finite models.
And I think there's a tremendous waste of effort and time in that.
And I would like to see...
some real coordination here again.
So, you know, excuse the interruption, but I think that has been the most interesting, but I think they have such a long way to go.
Because we know the meteorologists have tried this for years, and they still can't forecast more than a few days.
And although the ocean is more sluggish and
people hope for more accurate results from the same types of models.

I still think the complexity in the ocean is a long way away, even with the present models that we, you know, defining the complexity that we need in terms of fishery, specifically, is a long way away.
So that would be my comment.
